questions.stem: Before interview, what is a practical way to improve disclosure quality without being confrontational?

options.text: Demand 'everything you have' without specifics
Ask focused questions: what offence is alleged, key evidence relied upon, and what the interview will cover
Refuse to speak to the officer at all
Tell the client to guess what the allegation is

questions.explanation: Targeted disclosure requests are more effective. They help you advise and narrow the issues while creating a clear record of what was (and wasn’t) disclosed.

questions.stem: If disclosure remains minimal, what is the best way to protect the client from later unfair criticism of their interview stance?

options.text: Say nothing about disclosure limits
Record the disclosure limitations and your requests in writing/notes (and where appropriate, ensure the custody record reflects it)
Insult the officer to pressure them
Always advise a full account no matter what

questions.explanation: A clear record of what was disclosed and what was requested helps show the basis on which advice was given, and can support later fairness arguments if needed.

references.cite: Record keeping: advice basis and disclosure limitations (Check: guidance)

questions.stem: Which interview strategy is most defensible as a default when disclosure is limited?

options.text: A blanket 'no comment' in every case
A blanket full account in every case
A tailored strategy based on allegations, disclosure, and the client’s account (including considering a prepared statement)
Let the police decide what the client should say

questions.explanation: There is no one-size-fits-all. A tailored approach is professional and easier to justify later because it is grounded in the case facts and risks.

references.cite: Interview strategy and advising under limited disclosure (Check: guidance)

questions.stem: What is a key benefit of a prepared statement (when appropriate) under limited disclosure?

options.text: It guarantees no charge
It allows the client to put a consistent account forward while controlling risk and avoiding improvised answers
It replaces the need for interview attendance
It forces police to disclose everything

questions.explanation: A prepared statement can put forward key points (e.g., denial, limited admissions, alternative explanation) without the client being drawn into speculative detail. Whether it’s appropriate depends on the case.

references.cite: Prepared statements and interview strategy (Check: guidance)

questions.stem: Which disclosure request is most likely to be considered 'targeted' rather than a blanket demand?

options.text: “Give me your whole file.”
“Tell me exactly what my client is alleged to have done and what evidence you rely on for that allegation.”
“We are refusing interview until you disclose everything.”
“We need disclosure because it’s unfair otherwise.”

questions.explanation: Targeted requests focus on what you need to understand the allegation and advise. They are more likely to produce usable disclosure quickly than blanket demands.

questions.stem: A client wants to answer some questions but avoid others due to limited disclosure. What is the most professional way to structure that approach?

options.text: Answer randomly and refuse others without explanation
Agree a clear strategy: answer what can safely be answered, and for the rest use a consistent rationale linked to lack of disclosure
Refuse to attend interview because disclosure is limited
Let the police decide which questions are safe

questions.explanation: A structured approach is easier to justify and reduces the risk of inconsistent or speculative answers. It also creates a clear record of how disclosure limitations affected the strategy.

references.cite: Interview strategy under limited disclosure (Check: guidance)

questions.stem: If police say “We can’t disclose anything before interview,” what is a reasonable response?

options.text: Accept it without further questions
Ask at least for the allegation outline and what evidence category they rely on (e.g., witness, CCTV), and record their response
Threaten to sue the officer personally
Tell the client to confess to end the matter

questions.explanation: Even where full detail is not provided, you can seek a basic outline and evidence type to advise responsibly. Recording what was said helps later.

references.cite: Documenting disclosure requests and limitations (Check: guidance)

questions.stem: Which pitfall most often makes a disclosure-based strategy fail in practice?

options.text: Not writing anything down
Making strategy decisions without properly understanding the allegation and available disclosure
Asking police for clarification
Taking a break to advise the client

questions.explanation: Poor strategy usually comes from poor information: not clarifying the allegation/disclosure and then advising in a vacuum. Focus on understanding first, then advising.

references.cite: Advising: base decisions on allegation/disclosure (Check: guidance)
